SCIENTISTS have found the first direct evidence that ultraviolet rays penetrating the protective ozone layer over Antarctica are causing damage to the DNA of higher animals.

Since the late 1970's, the natural layer of ozone in the stratosphere has thinned over the Antarctic continent, and during each Southern Hemisphere spring scientists have come to expect the opening of an ozone ''hole'' lasting for several weeks.
The thinning of the ozone layer throughout the world is believed to be mainly the result of damage caused by chlorofluorocarbons released from refrigerators, air-conditioners and propellants.

In recent years, investigators have found that algae -- plant microorganisms living on the underside of Antarctic sea ice -- have suffered reduced reproduction rates that many scientists ascribe to the ozone hole. Algae are at the bottom of the food chain, and they are vital to the survival of marine animals.

In a report published last month in The Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, scientists from Northeastern University in Boston and the University of Texas at Austin said that during the period when the ozone hole was most intense they found extensive DNA lesions, or damage, in the eggs and larvae of icefish -- Antarctic fish that lack hemoglobin.
Dr. William Detrich of Northeastern said, ''It is striking how closely the damage to the fish eggs tracked with the increased intensity of ultraviolet light.''
